title: R44043
content: The President appoints individuals to federal government positions, some using sole authority while others require Senate advice and consent. This report for the 113th Congress details nominations for full-time positions on 34 boards and commissions, including leadership structure, membership, and appointment activity. It also outlines statutory requirements for these positions. The report for the 113th Congress details nominations for full-time positions on 34 boards and commissions, including membership, terms of office, political balance, and appointment activity. Information was compiled using the Senate nominations database. The report for the 113th Congress details nominations for full-time positions on 34 boards and commissions, including membership, terms of office, political balance, and appointment activity. Information was compiled from various sources such as the nominations database of the Legislative Information System (LIS), Congressional Record, Weekly Compilation of Presidential Documents, agency websites, United States Code, and the 2012 Plum Book. Congressional Research Service (CRS) reports on presidential appointments process and related matters can be found at http://www.crs.gov. Federal executive branch boards and commissions discussed in the report share common characteristics, including being independent bodies located outside executive departments, having multiple members appointed by the President, and at least one member serving full time. The members of federal executive branch boards and commissions are appointed by the President with Senate approval, serving fixed terms with restricted removal power. Terms have set beginning and end dates to ensure leadership continuity, with staggered end dates to prevent simultaneous departures. The President may nominate individuals for board positions to complete unexpired terms or upcoming terms, ensuring leadership continuity. In some cases, the same person may be nominated for both the unexpired term and the succeeding term simultaneously. The chair of some commissions must be confirmed by the Senate and appointed from among the current commissioners. The President can appoint someone who is not on the commission as chair by submitting two nominations simultaneously - one for member and one for chair. Executive branch boards and commissions have political independence from the President, but he can influence membership by designating the chair or filling vacancies. President George W. Bush shaped the SEC and National Labor Relations Board by filling vacancies during his first two years in office. During the 113th Congress, President Obama submitted nominations for vacancies on the National Labor Relations Board and other boards and commissions. Some bodies have limits on the number of members from the same political party, and advice and consent requirements apply to certain appointments. During the 113th Congress, President Obama submitted nominations for 86 out of 149 full-time positions on various boards and commissions. A total of 114 nominations were submitted, with 77 confirmed, 7 withdrawn, and 30 returned. Multiple nominations were made for some positions, including reappointments and second choices. At the end of the Congress, 24 incumbents were serving past their terms. During the 113th Congress, President Obama submitted nominations for 86 out of 149 full-time positions on various boards and commissions. A total of 114 nominations were submitted, with 77 confirmed, 7 withdrawn, and 30 returned. In addition, there were 22 vacancies among the positions. The average number of days elapsed from nomination to confirmation was 124.2, with a median of 112.0 days. Each of the 34 board or commission profiles in this report is organized into three parts. It includes details on the appointed positions, terms of office, political balance requirements, and appointment actions. The section also identifies agencies' positions requiring Senate confirmation and the incumbents in those positions. It also mentions the appointment actions for each nomination in chronological order. The curr_chunk provides information on nominations in chronological order, including nominee names, positions, submission and confirmation dates, and actions taken. It also mentions cases where multiple nominations were submitted for the same nominee. Tables with multiple confirmed nominations show the average number of days for confirmation. The curr_chunk discusses the calculation of the mean number of days for confirmation of nominations to regulatory and collegial boards during the 113th Congress. It includes tables with nomination and confirmation dates, actions taken, and average confirmation days for multiple nominations. The curr_chunk provides summary information on appointments and nominations to independent boards and commissions, including details on vacancies, confirmations, nominations returned, and recess appointments. It also includes information on the Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board and the appointment process for its members. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission, Consumer Product Safety Commission, and Defense Nuclear Facilities Safety Board each have five members serving terms of five, seven, and unspecified lengths respectively, with restrictions on political party representation. Members can stay in office for a period after their term ends unless replaced, and the chair is appointed by the President with Senate approval. The Election Assistance Commission, Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, and Board each have members serving terms with restrictions on political party representation. Members can continue to serve after their term ends until a successor is appointed. The chair and vice chair positions are designated by the respective commissions. The President appoints the chair, vice chair, and general counsel of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. Members can serve for up to four years, and an incumbent can continue until a successor is qualified. The President also appoints an inspector general. The Farm Credit Administration has three members serving six-year terms, with one designated as chair by the President. The Federal Communications Commission has five members serving five-year terms, with the President designating the chair. Members can continue to serve until a successor is appointed. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation Board of Directors consists of five members, with appointed members serving six-year terms. The President appoints the chair and vice chair, with the advice and consent of the Senate. The Federal Election Commission consists of six members, with no more than three from the same political party. The Election Commission, Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, and Federal Labor Relations Authority each have a specific number of members from different political parties serving terms of varying lengths. The chair and vice chair positions rotate annually, with the President designating the chair for the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. The Federal Maritime Commission, Federal Mine Safety and Health Review Commission, and Federal Reserve System Board of Governors each have a specific number of members serving terms of varying lengths. The President designates the chair for each commission. The Federal Reserve System Board of Governors consists of 7 members serving 14-year terms. The President appoints the chair and vice chair for 4-year terms with Senate approval. The Federal Trade Commission has five members serving seven-year terms, with the President designating the chair. The Financial Stability Oversight Council has 10 voting members chaired by the Secretary of the Treasury. The Foreign Claims Settlement Commission has three members serving three-year terms, with the chair appointed by the President and serving full time. The Merit Systems Protection Board consists of three members with no more than two serving from the same political party. The Merit Systems Protection Board has three members serving seven-year terms, with the President appointing the chair. The National Credit Union Administration Board of Directors consists of three members serving six-year terms, with the President designating the chair. The National Labor Relations Board has five members serving five-year terms. The National Mediation Board, National Transportation Safety Board, and their respective members have specific terms and appointment processes. The President appoints members with limitations on political party representation, and designates chairs with Senate approval. Members can continue to serve until successors are appointed. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission, Occupational Safety and Health Review Commission, and Postal Regulatory Commission have specific membership structures and appointment processes. Members serve for specific terms, with limitations on political party representation, and the President designates the chair. The President also appoints the inspector general for each commission. The Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board consists of five members serving six-year terms, with the chair appointed by the President. The President designates the chair, and members select the vice chair. When a term expires, a member may continue to serve until a successor takes office, but not for more than one year after the term would expire. The Implementing Recommendations of the 9/11 Commission Act of 2007 established the Board. The Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board consists of five members serving six-year terms, with the chair appointed by the President. The board ceased functioning on January 30, 2008. The Railroad Retirement Board has three members serving five-year terms. The President appoints the chair and an inspector general with Senate approval. The Securities and Exchange Commission has five members serving five-year terms, with the President designating the chair. The Surface Transportation Board, part of the Department of Transportation, has three members serving five-year terms. The President designates the chair. The United States International Trade Commission has six members serving nine-year terms, with the President appointing the chair and vice chair for two-year terms. The United States Parole Commission is an independent agency in the Department of Justice with five commissioners serving six-year terms. The commission can be extended beyond term limits until a successor is appointed. The President designates the chair, and the commission's lifespan has been extended multiple times by Congress. The United States Sentencing Commission is a judicial branch agency with seven voting members appointed to six-year terms. The United States Parole Commission has seven voting members appointed by the President with Senate approval. The chair and three vice chairs serve full time, with at least three members being federal judges. No more than four members can be from the same political party, and no voting member can serve more than two full terms. The Attorney General serves as a nonvoting member, and the chair of the United States Parole Commission is also a nonvoting member. The State Parole Commission is an ex officio nonvoting member of the commission. (18 U.S.C. §3551 note)
